Let the rotation be at $ R.P.S $.
Consider an element at P (Fig. 128).
Then—

\[ dF = -\frac{dF}{d\theta} d\theta \]  

and  

\[ \tan \phi = \frac{\text{weight of particle}}{\text{horizontal force}} = \frac{dF}{dF_{c}} \]  

Representing the variables  

\[ \frac{dF}{dF_{c}} = \frac{dF}{\rho g\text{radius}} = \frac{\rho v^{2}}{g}\cdot \frac{r}{\rho v}\cdot \frac{dr}{\rho g} \]  

where $ \rho $ is a constant, and thus this is the equation of a parabolic arc revolving.

Example 37—Prove that a cubic parabola is a suitable "transition" curve.

In order that the full curvature of a railway curve may be passed gradually, a curve known as a transition curve is used to join the straight and the curve. It must be noted that the radius of curvature varies inversely as the distance from the starting point of the straight, where the radius is infinite;  

or more exactly  

\[ y = \frac{x^{3}}{3\left(\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}\right)_{0}} + C \]

blocks.description: This equation represents the cubic parabola in context of transition curves.
